You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

We use the following function to calculate the factorial of an unsigned integer `n`:
```
unsigned int factorial(unsigned int n)
{
    unsigned int result = 1;
    for(unsigned int i=1; i<=n; i++)
    {
        result *= i;
    }
    return result;
}
```

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

- `x` is a float variable initialized to an unknown value.
- `pi` is a float variable initialized to 3.14159.
- `octant` is a float variable initialized to the value of `pi/3`.
- `oddExp` is a float variable initialized to the value of `x`.
- `evenExp` is a float variable initialized to the value of 1.0.
- `term` is a float variable initialized to the value of `x`.
- `count` is an unsigned int variable initialized to the value of 2.
- `multFactor` is an int variable initialized to 0.
- `temp` is an int variable initialized to an unknown value.

Loop condition:
- The loop runs indefinitely since the condition is `while(1)`.

Loop invariants:
- `oddExp >= x` (before loop execution)
- `evenExp <= x + 1.0` (before loop execution)
- `multFactor == 1 || multFactor == -1` (in every iteration of the loop)
- `count % 2 == 0 ==> evenExp >= oddExp` (in every iteration of the loop)
- `count % 2 == 1 ==> oddExp >= evenExp` (in every iteration of the loop)
- `term <= x * octant / (count * (count-1))` (in every iteration of the loop)
- `count >= 2` (in every iteration of the loop)
- `(temp != 0) ==> (oddExp >= evenExp)` (after loop termination, assuming that `temp` has a non-zero value)

Explanation:
- `oddExp` is initialized to `x`, so `oddExp >= x` is true before the loop execution.
- `evenExp` is initialized to `1.0`, so `evenExp <= x + 1.0` is true before the loop execution.
- `multFactor` is assigned either `1` or `-1` based on the value of `count`, so `multFactor == 1 || multFactor == -1` is true in every iteration of the loop.
- In each iteration, either `evenExp` or `oddExp` is updated, depending on the value of `count`. If `count` is even, then `evenExp` is updated, and if `count` is odd, then `oddExp` is updated. Therefore, if `count` is even, then `evenExp` is greater than or equal to `oddExp`, i.e., `count % 2 == 0 ==> evenExp >= oddExp`. Similarly, if `count` is odd, then `oddExp` is greater than or equal to `evenExp`, i.e., `count % 2 == 1 ==> oddExp >= evenExp`.
- The value of `term` is updated in each iteration by multiplying it with `(x/count)` twice. Therefore, the maximum value of `term` occurs when `count` is `2`, and its value is `x * octant / (2 * (2-1))`, i.e., `term <= x * octant / (count * (count-1))`.
- `count` is initialized to `2`, and it is incremented by `1` in each iteration. Therefore, `count` is always greater than or equal to `2`, i.e., `count >= 2`.
- The assertion `oddExp >= evenExp` is guarded by the condition `temp == 0`, which means that if the loop terminates because `temp` is `0`, then the assertion does not need to hold. Therefore, we use an implication to make the invariant trivially true if `temp` is non-zero, i.e., `(temp != 0) ==> (oddExp >= evenExp)`.

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**

llm_conversation.content:
You are a helpful AI software assistant that reasons about how code behaves. Given a program, you can find loop invariants, which can then be used to verify some property in the program. 
Frama-C is a software verification tool for C programs. The input to Frama-C is a C program file with ACSL (ANSI/ISO C Specification Language) annotations.
For the given program, find the necessary loop invariants of the while loop to help Frama-C verify the post-condition.

Instructions:
- Make a note of the pre-conditions or variable assignments in the program.
- Analyze the loop body and make a note of the loop condition. 
- Output loop invariants that are true 
(i) before the loop execution, 
(ii) in every iteration of the loop and 
(iii) after the loop termination, 
such that the loop invariants imply the post condition.
- If a loop invariant is a conjunction, split it into its parts.
- Output all the loop invariants in one code block. For example:
```
/*@ 
    loop invariant i1;
    loop invariant i2;
*/
```
Rules:
- **Do not use variables or functions that are not declared in the program.** 
- **Do not make any assumptions about functions whose definitions are not given.**
- **All undefined variables contain garbage values. Do not use variables that have garbage values.**
- **Do not use keywords that are not supported in ACSL annotations for loops.**
- **Variables that are not explicitly initialized, could have garbage values. Do not make any assumptions about such values.**
- **Do not use the \at(x, Pre) notation for any variable x.**
- **Do not use non-deterministic function calls.**
